title: Fix an inconsistent doc link
body:
Previously, all links with anchors have trailing slashes, e.g., `$guides/tables/#fills`.
However, #6905 introduced a `$guides/accessibility#artifacts`, which might be okay for the official website, but it causes problems for a downstream unofficial project.
This PR adds the missing trailing slash.

```bash
$ rg '\(\$guides/.+#.+\)' --only-matching --no-filename | sort | uniq -c
      1 ($guides/accessibility#artifacts)
      2 ($guides/accessibility/#basics)
      6 ($guides/accessibility/#textual-representations)
      2 ($guides/page-setup/#columns)
      1 ($guides/page-setup/#columns))
      1 ($guides/page-setup/#page-numbers)
      1 ($guides/tables/#alignment)
      2 ($guides/tables/#fills)
      1 ($guides/tables/#strokes)
```

title: Revert math precedence change
body:
As many of you are probably aware, Typst 0.14 was supposed to fix the long-standing issue that `$f_i(x)` renders the `(x)` in the subscript. The relevant change was made in https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6442 after lengthy considerations and discussion spread across Discord and the [Forum](https://forum.typst.app/t/opinions-needed-likely-upcoming-changes-to-math-mode-precedence/4974).

However, a new case that hasn't previously been considered and whose behavior has regressed with #6442 has now come to light in [discussions on Discord](https://discord.com/channels/1054443721975922748/1054443722592497796/1425567766764716152) (specifically the parsing precedence in `$ 1 / f_a(x) $`).

There is a potential fix for this issue in https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/7072. However, that PR only revealed deeper issues with the design and we're not confident that it  is the best we can do for Typst.

**As we don't want to put the burden on users to migrate their documents twice, we have thus decided to revert and postpone the change. That said, we are still committed to fixing the rendering of `$f_i(x)$`.**

In particular, we are planning to prioritize a more holistical reconsideration of all edge cases and issues of the current math syntax, so that we can make one confident change rather than spread-out, disruptive fixes.

This reverts commit 7dc99e92ecec28cd62436e344cebc3052c756ac3.

title: Streamline docs for typed HTML API
body:
Makes the HTML typed docs more useful and less noisy by
- rendering all functions on one page
- rendering global attributes only once in a separate list

The typed HTML docs will also be excluded from the search.

title: Update German translations
body:
- Email is a material (vitreous enamel in English)
- Bibliographie is the old spelling and we should use the new spelling for consistency (otherwise Telefon would have to be Telephon)

title: Fix panic in krilla when `surface.pop()` isn't executed
body:
This fixes a few cases where krilla would panic because `surface.pop` wasn't called when the function bailed in between the `push` and `pop` calls.

As a side note, I finally wrapped my head around how to implement a generalized mechanism to defer cleanup code, and I quite like this aproach. I think it could be come in handy in other scenarios :)

title: Mention that PDF image's version must be <= export version in docs
Disable tagged PDF export when using the --pages option
body:
Fixes #7047.

This disables tagged PDF export when using the `--pages` option.
Additionally a warning is emitted when `--no-pdf-tags` isn't used.
And a hint is added to the error when an accessible PDF standard is specified.

Hints from application level errors previously weren't printed.

title: Fix typos 2
body:
I ran the [`typos`](https://github.com/crate-ci/typos) tool on `typst/typst`, and sifted through false positives:
* General typos.
* Spelling of Typst, reminded of by https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/7056#discussion_r2413210926.

There's also instances of *queriable* -> *queryable* scattered around, but I believe it reaches too much into the code, and might not appear as incorrect to most people. Still, it's inconsistent with [`docs.rs`](https://docs.rs/typst/latest/typst/introspection/trait.Unqueriable.html) where the description correctly uses `y`. I couldn't find any instance of `queryable` in `typst/typst`, but around 15 of `queriable`.

This is sort of a follow-up to my previous typo-related PR https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6878.

title: Fix PDF tag structure validation error message
body: I forgot to update the error message when I generalized this code.

title: Fix unused function warning in release builds
body: The `iter` method is only used when `debug_assertions` are enabled.

title: Add section on PDF versions
Typst 0.14 changelog
body:
There are a ton of great changes in this one, so making a selection for the highlights section was tricky!

This is the first changelog that links out to the relevant PRs for each item, as was requested on Discord a while ago. At first I was skeptical because I feared that it would make the changelog visually noisy, but we found a nice solution: The links are automatically turned into small chain icons (that are easy to ignore) by the docs CSS.

title: More examples for `frac.style`
body: Also worth mentioning in the guide for LaTeX users.

title: Validate PDF tag structure
body:
Fixes #7054.

This PR introduces a PDF tag structure validation check for tables, lists, and outlines.

title: Output OS and ISA arch for typst info
body: Helpful to differentiate between WSL and native Windows, Docker and native macOS, x86 vs x86_64...

title: Switch docker metadata action into semver mode
body:
Fixes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/5864 by switching the metadata action into semver mode.

Aside from not tagging prereleases as latest, this also means that the docker tags won't have a leading `v` anymore, which is more typical (e.g. `ghcr.io/typst/typst:0.14.0` instead of `ghcr.io/typst/typst:v0.14.0`).

I also noticed that I consistently got semver prerelease versions wrong: I spelled it `0.13.0-rc1` instead of `0.13.0-rc.1` across Git and Cargo.toml. I'll use the correct syntax going forward.

title: Add optional non-root user to Dockerfile
body:
This PR adds a non-root user to the Dockerfile but does not enable it by default.

Many organizations, like [OWASP](https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Docker_Security_Cheat_Sheet.html#rule-2-set-a-user), [NIST](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/specialpublications/nist.sp.800-190.pdf), and the [CNCF](https://www.cncf.io/blog/2023/12/15/best-practices-for-securing-kubernetes-deployments/) recommend to run Docker images as unprivileged users. This is a defense-in-depth measure that adds an additional security layer protecting against attacks that use a vulnerability in the image and a container runtime exploit to gain root privileges on the host machine.

However, using the `USER` directive to change to a non-root user breaks downstream consumers of the image. For example, this would not work anymore if we activated a non-root user by default:

```Dockerfile
FROM typst:latest
RUN apk add additional-tool  # FAILS - permission denied
```

This is why many industry containers do not change to another user. Instead, many images, like NodeJS and Gradle, instead create a new user that then can be activated when running the container using the `--user` flag. Since we do not want to break dependents, we will handle this similarly.

We assigned the user and the group ID 1000, which match the default first user ID on many Linux systems. This is intended to make it possible to read from mounted volumes containing files created on the host. Advanced users may need to change the IDs or create their own users to accomodate their permission scenarios.

The exploit chain against which running as a non-root user protects looks like this:

1. The attacker exploits Typst or Alpine Linux to gain process privileges
2. The attacker exploits and escapes the container runtime through a vulnerability like [CVE-2019-5736](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2019-5736), [CVE-2022-0492](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2022-0492), or [CVE-2024-21626](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2024-21626)
3. The attacker is now root on the whole server

With the user enabled, the runtime exploit can be harder and the attacker needs an additional privilege escalation to become root on the host.

title: Avoid release action from updating prerelease status
body: The action changes the status of the GitHub release from prerelease to latest when updating artifacts, which has to be undone manually.

title: Warn for optional content groups in PDF images
body:
See https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/7043#pullrequestreview-3310373637

@LaurenzV I reworded the hints a bit because just "Flatten the PDF before embedding it." might be a bit obtuse for a user. Do you think it's clear enough like this?

title: Fix bug with table/grid cells that are used internally or are artifacts
body:
Fixes #7030.

The error was a result of a bug in the tagging code.

Additionally this improves the error messages when tags couldn't be split:
- In non `PDF/UA` mode this error should never ocurr, change the hint to reflect that.
- Only report `PDF/UA` error if the error was caused by the stricter `PDF/UA` rules, not just because `PDF/UA` is targeted.
- When the inner tags only have detached spans, report the outer span.

title: Spanish translations for footnote, email, and telephone
Add Italian translations for email and telephone
body: Add Italian translation for terms introduced in #6619.

title: Disallow empty URLs
body: In addition to URLs that are too long, this commit disallows empty URLs in links. This addresses two PDF/UA-1 validation issues found by veraPDF on the old test `link-empty-block`: Clause 7.18.1 (test 2) and Clause 7.18.5 (test 2). Both stipulate that a non-empty contents key must be present on annotations. Because we set the `Contents` key to the URL, empty URLs fail this test. But they don't make sense anyways, so we just forbid them here.

title: Add note about `args` module in `typst-cli`
body: Encountered during initial work for the `--ignore-embedded-fonts` flag.

title: Invert `disable_pdf_tags` into `tagged` in `PdfOptions`
body: The positive condition is just a bit simpler generally in my opinion. The CLI is an exception because `true` is the default, so `false` needs an inverted flag to be enabled.

title: Update Chinese translations
body: Add translations in Simplified and Traditional Chinese for terms introduced in #6619.

title: Turn PDF images into SVGs in HTML and SVG export
body: Using [`hayro-svg`](https://crates.io/crates/hayro-svg). Huge props to @LaurenzV once again.

title: Disable `embed-fonts` feature in hayro
body: The fonts are already embedded on the Typst side. Also added a test for this that was prepared in https://github.com/typst/typst-dev-assets/pull/11, but never added on the Typst side.

title: Bump codex to released version
Add missing elements to introspector that were filtered out
body:
Fixes #7015. The commit 77076ce22 introduced `TagFlags` that are used to filter which elements are added to the introspector and which are handled in tagged PDF generation. This wouldn't add elements to the introspector that aren't `Locatable` or haven't been labelled. So in case of the bibliography the `DirectLinkElem` which isn't locatable wasn't inserted into the introspector, and thus when getting the position to link to, `(0, 0)` was returned.

Now any element that has a manually assigned location will also be marked as `introspectable` and inserted into the introspector.

title: Bump krilla and expose the remaining PDF/A standards
body:
Closes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/7007
Closes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/2942

title: Add `--ignore-embedded-fonts` option
body:
Supersedes #7034 (no structification).

Fixes #7018.

title: Add tests from #7003
body: This adds some of the tests from #7003 that I think are worth keeping in the test suite.

title: Add test for positions of elements at the start of a paragraph
Update Slovenian translation
body:
Adds Slovenian translations for footnote, email, and telephone.

Possible less common alternatives:
* `footnote: Sprotna opomba`
* `email: E-naslov`

title: Update Danish translations for email and telephone
body: Changed page from "side" to "Side" to match case of other entries

title: Fix check for PDF figures containing only marked content
body:
Fixes an inverted condition when checking if a Typst figure contains only marked content. If a Typst figure contains only marked content a PDF `Figure` tag should be used. If not (because there is a nested tag structure) a `Div` tag will be used instead.

This bug caused figures containing structured content (such as listings) to emit a `PDF/UA-1` error complaining about missing alt text, and vice versa would not generate an error for figures containing only marked content that didn't have a alt text.

title: Update Dutch translation
body:
This PR translates the new terms introduced by #6619, and fixes one mistake from the translations imported by #6852.

### footnote
Translated as 'voetnoot', the original 'voetnote' is not a valid Dutch word. 
('voetnote' might be a literal translation of the English 'footnote', or accidentally copied from [Afrikaans](https://gesellig.co.za/m/136737/) - though I couldn't find an official source for this.)

### email
Translated as 'e-mail', following the [style rules](https://taaladvies.net/over/) set out by taaladvies.net:
- [Always starts with lowercase](https://taaladvies.net/e-mail-hoofdletter/)
- [Always written with a hyphen](https://taaladvies.net/email-of-e-mail/)

### telephone
Translated as 'telefoon'. According to https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/7010#issuecomment-3365373684, this could also be changed to 'telefoonnummer', if that is the intended meaning.

title: Update Irish (Gaeilge) translation
body: Added missing Irish translations for Typst and corrected one existing translation.

title: Fix panic because of missing content in PDF tag tree
Add `--deps` and `--deps-format` flags for emitting a dependency list
body:
This PR replaces `--make-deps` with two new flags:
- `--deps` — where to write the list of dependencies
- `--deps-format` — one of `zero`, `json`, `make`:
  - `make`: Makefile format, matches the behavior of `--make-deps`
    ```Makefile
    main.pdf: lib.typ /home/tau/.cache/typst/packages/preview/physica/0.9.6/physica.typ /home/tau/.cache/typst/packages/preview/physica/0.9.6/typst.toml main.typ image.png
    ```
  - `json`: JSON array of strings, each string being a (relative) path to a dependency
    ```json
    ["lib.typ","/home/tau/.cache/typst/packages/preview/physica/0.9.6/physica.typ","/home/tau/.cache/typst/packages/preview/physica/0.9.6/typst.toml","main.typ","image.png"]
    ```
  - `zero`: sequence of strings delimited by a NUL byte
    ```
    lib.typ␀/home/tau/.cache/typst/packages/preview/physica/0.9.6/physica.typ␀/home/tau/.cache/typst/packages/preview/physica/0.9.6/typst.toml␀main.typ␀image.png␀
    ```
    
Comparison of formats:

Name | Human-readable (-2..=+2) | Machine-readable (-2..=+2) | Allowed dependency paths 
---- | ------------------------ | -------------------------- | ------------------------
Makefile       | `+1` | `-1` (largely unstandardized, essentially defined by an implementation — in fact, `--make-deps` was implemented by rewriting a part of GCC in Rust, and the GCC code says something like "well GNU Make does this; note that this still breaks sometimes") | Valid Unicode without certain characters like `$`
JSON           | `0` (can be improved to `+1` by using "pretty" option) | `+1` (standard is short and concise, easy to implement in any language, used by most utilities, but still requires stuff like escape processing) | Valid Unicode
Zero/Null/text0 | `-0.5` (needs `bat -A` or similar) | `+2` (doesn't require any sort of escape parsing, can be parsed without copying) | Anything without NUL (which AFAIK is forbidden on all existing systems)

Scale used:
- (-2, +2) is Protobuf and similar (cannot be read by a human, close to a memory dump for a machine)
- (0, 0) is something like XML (still can be read by a layperson and is well-defined, but is quite verbose and requires effort from both)
- (+2, -2) is a free-form natural language description (the native tongue for humans, absolutely unreadable for machines, and even complicated NLP stuff is still imperfect)

Unresolved questions:
- [ ] What should be the default `--deps-format`? Currently it's `zero`, because it's the only lossless one, but I admit it's not the most common format. Maybe use JSON as the middle ground?
- [ ] Should JSON be minified?
- [ ] What should be the name of the NUL-delimited format? It's too simple to have a standard (the only possible disagreement is whether the file should include a trailing NUL, but I haven't yet seen a tool not including one), so there's no standard name. I chose `zero`, because `null` can be confused for "lack of value", and `text0` is a bit longer and includes combines letters and digits, which a part of my brain doesn't like for some reason.

(continuation of #6648)

title: Update Galician translations
body:
- Translate the new terms from 069388945258cbeda0b370b32e001075894ec1b8

title: Change tutorial to accomodate `title`
body:
After the introduction of the title element, using the text function to create a title manually is bad practice. I updated the tutorial accordingly.

To make the goal of the tutorial possible, I added an explanation of set show rules. Furthermore, I mentioned the `block` function. Finally, I changed the document title to title case.

title: Improve example rendering of parameters and nested functions
body: This PR changes the presentation of examples for nested functions and parameters. Previously, this was the behavior: - Examples for nested functions got pulled below the summary - Examples for parameters were collapsed at the end of its docs, below the default Furthermore, the first instance of three backticks started the example, and all of the markup below was pulled into the collapsible widget or below the summary. Now, examples appear in reading order. They terminate after their code fence ends, normal text can be below them. They are always in collapsible drawers, but for a nested function, the first example is expanded by default. Furthermore, examples can now be disambiguated with titles by using the `:"Example title"` syntax in the code fence tag. This PR introduces some example titles. **Parameter with multiple examples:** **Nested function with multiple examples** Fixes #6922

title: Add French translations
body:
This adds some French translations.

The actual French word for "email" would be "courriel" or "mél" but I don't think anyone uses those words in the real world.

Also, depending on where those translations are used, it might be better to use "Adresse mail" ("E-mail address") and "Numéro de téléphone" ("Phone number").

title: Do not crash for zero-sized images in PDF export
body: Fixes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/6255

title: Fix panic on negative text size
body: Closes #5940

title: Fix regressions in EXIF orientation handling
body:
Fixes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/6913

Regression introduced in https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6102/ which was guided by https://sirv.com/help/articles/rotate-photos-to-be-upright/, but the image in that blog post is wrong. The image there displays the same information as the ASCII art on http://sylvana.net/jpegcrop/exif_orientation.html, but what this graphic is supposed to display is _what the letter F would look like if it were tagged correctly and displayed by a program that ignores the orientation tag._ (Basically, different Fs baked with rotations and an EXIF value that cancels it). What we were really looking for though is an illustration of how an image is supposed to look with no baked rotation and just the EXIF value in a program that does _not_ ignore the orientation tag. I generated 8 such images and confirmed that the Typst output now again looks the same as what Apple Preview renders.

Moreover, since the introduction of krilla, we considered the EXIF rotation twice for non-JPEG images, once by baking it into the dynamic image and once in the PDF output with a transform. For JPEG, the first one didn't happen because JPEGs don't get recoded anymore and our only test is for JPEG, hence it didn't surface. ~~I didn't add a test for this yet because I would first need to find or construct a non-JPEG image with EXIF rotation, which is too much effort now (contribution welcome!)~~

title: Expand and improve examples for array methods
body:
This pull request enhances the documentation for several methods in the `array` module to improve
clarity and provide better examples for users.

The following functions have been updated:

- **`dedup`**: The example has been changed to `(3, 3, 1, 2, 3)`. This new example better illustrates
that `dedup` preserves the order of the first-seen elements and does not perform any sorting, which the
previous example could have misleadingly implied.
- **`enumerate`**: Added a `for` loop example to demonstrate destructuring of the index-value pairs.
- **`fold` & `reduce`**: Added examples to clarify the accumulator pattern and unified the variable
names in the examples for consistency.
- **`split` & `intersperse`**: Added examples and explained their conceptual inverse relationship to
make their behavior easier to grasp.

title: Bump `zip`
Bump wasmi and enable its `simd` feature
body: Closes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/6679

title: Deduplicate `window-sys` dependency
Deprecate renamed `modern-humanities-research-association` style
body:
Depends on #6171

With the new hayagriva version, this style is deprecated in favor of `modern-humanities-research-association-notes`.

title: More helpful error message for footnotes in combination with custom `<html>` or `<body>`
body: Closes #6939

title: Remove outdated `set_location` call on citations
body: I'm not even entirely sure what the purpose of this was (it was added years ago). I think it was something related to backlinks and saving one layout iteration, but it shouldn't have any sensible effect anymore, it does not affect any tests, and it is conceptually very wrong as locations are supposed to be unique IDs. Having different types of elements with the same location breaks various assumptions.

title: Consistently shift links in PDF a bit vertically
body:
This is how it used to work but one place was missed in https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/5420. This PR factors the behaviour out into a function, such that it is not missed again.

This is necessary because e.g. the position of backlinks to footnotes is always at the baseline and if you link directly to it, the text will not be visible since it is right above.

title: Revise DOM for footnotes in HTML
body: While `doc-footnote` seems like the right role at first, the semantics of `doc-endnotes` are a bit better match for what we're doing and using it means a cleaner DOM structure (one div less per footnote, better placement of `id` attributes) that is more in line with the outline and the bibliography (which are structurally similar). The updated DOM is also in line with what pandoc does.

title: Ignore CSL's `display="left-margin"` in block-level containers
body:
The CSL `display="left-margin"` attribute is meant for top-level use. The CSL spec isn't clear what should happen when it is used in a container, but not a single style from https://github.com/citation-style-language/styles/ uses it in such a context anyway.

Citeproc.js (which is basically the reference implementation) seems to just ignore it. We currently created a nested grid. This doesn't translate so well to HTML and is essentially somewhat overcomplicated dead code. In citations, we used to completely disregard any content marked with this display attribute. Now, the attribute is consistently just ignored in places where it is not supported.

title: Use semantic text formatting elements in bibliography
body:
This PR switches from direct text style settings to semantic elements (e.g. `strong` instead of `weight: "bold"`) in the bibliography output. While the CSL spec talks about `font-weight: "bold"`, it's likely that that's just because it has no notion of semantical elements. The benefits of a strict reading of the spec are also rather questionable, while using semantical elements makes the bibliography easier to style and works out of the box in HTML export.

For what it's worth, pandoc also creates a `<strong>` element in its CSL processing. Interestingly, the [online CSL editor](https://editor.citationstyles.org/codeEditor/), which I think uses citeproc.js, creates a `<b>` element. This doesn't really make sense as a direct translation of bold either though since that element's semantics are "Bring Attention To" and not simply "Bold".

Closes #6639.

title: Introduce internal `DirectLinkElem` as a temporary workaround
body:
This is a temporary hack that introduces an element which can be used to create links across HTML and paged export that do not react to `show link` rules. This is the current behaviour of `ref`, `cite`, `footnote`, etc. and means that these are not adversely affected by `show link: underline` rules in paged export.

In the future, we'll want to migrate everything to normal links (see https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/5614), but to do that, I'd first like to have a simpler way to style only URL links. https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6903 was an attempt at that, but it has some problems. Another option would be a synthesized field `kind` on `link` that could be used, e.g. `show link.where(kind: "url"): underline`. However, I decided to not rush the design on that after all, so for now we've got this temporary hack that maintains the status quo while unblocking progress on HTML export.

title: Fix a typo in the plugin doc
body:
_most_ → _must_.

Resolves https://github.com/typst/webapp-issues/issues/729

title: Fix box corner radius clamp when missing strokes
body:
Closes #6938 

Resolves the issue #6938 where disabling one side’s stroke prevented the adjacent corner radius from ever reaching its full extent. 

The previous implementation clamped all four radii against a single maximum derived from the thinnest stroke. To be specific, every corner radius was clamped against a single global  `max_radius = min(width, height) / 2 + min(stroke_half_widths)`. The `stroke_half_widths` come from halving each active side’s stroke thickness and substituting 0 when a side is absent. When you disabled the right stroke, its contribution became 0, so `min(stroke_half_widths)` collapsed to 0. All corners, including the left one, were now capped at just `min(width, height) / 2`.

We now derive a per-corner limiting radius instead of a global one. For each corner we combine the base half-size `min(width, height) / 2` with the tighter of the two adjacent stroke half-widths. This matches the actual geometric constraint: the corner’s outer arc is bounded by the two strokes that meet there. 

As a consequence, removing the right stroke now only reduces the `max_radius` of top-right and bottom-right corners, and no longer influences the top-left and bottom-left corners.

title: Fix crash when the body of a context expression is a closure
body:
Closes #6800 

The problem is exactly what @laurmaedje said [in this comment:](https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/6800#issuecomment-3218107307) The evaluating code can confuse a "normal" closure with a "synthetic" closure produced by a `context` expression.

The solution is to clearly differentiate the types of closures. I used an enum that wraps the `SyntaxNode` of the closure. I initially tried to make the enum members wrap a `ast::Closure` / `ast::Expr` explicitly but that would come with viral declarations of lifetimes. Since that would require major refactorings I wanted to avoid that. I couldn't see a solution without the lifetimes so I decided to keep the wrapped data as it was.

Also I struggled to make a meaningful test for this case. Since the output of this "closure-in-context" is nonsense anyway (rendered as `(..) => ..`) I decided to make a minimal reproduction and leave it at that.

Any pointers to improvements and constructive criticisms are more than welcome.

title: Cargo.lock: update stacker
body:
Using stacker < 0.1.19 panics when building anything but trivial code with /proc hidden (as can happen in some CI, but can be reproduced with e.g. bwrap)

```
$ bwrap --dev-bind /dev /dev --ro-bind /usr /usr \
        --ro-bind /lib /lib --ro-bind /lib64 /lib64  \
        --ro-bind $PWD $PWD \
        ./target/release/typst compile - - <<<'#list[a][b]'

thread 'main' panicked at ~/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-1949cf8c6b5b557f/stacker-0.1.17/src/lib.rs:412:13:
assertion `left == right` failed
  left: 2
 right: 0
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace
```

Bumping stacker brings in improved error handling[1], which fixes the issue (arguably guessing stack size does not work but that does not seem to be a big problem)

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/stacker/commit/5eed05f39c2c71cb9153a94e27826535ed6d545b [1]


-----------------------

This is a bit far fetched but panic isn't great ergonomics and it took me a few minutes to understand what was going on here (I'll just have /proc available from now on :p)
I'm not sure how the Cargo.lock update policy is, I just ran `cargo update stacker` for this as 0.1.19 has been out since Feb and it doesn't look like it wouldn't get updated quickly otherwise.
(note it doesn't seem to impact the rust-version, which is much newer for Typst than stacker -- the window-sys version rollback seems to be something gone wrong in #5808 as only 0.52.0 and 0.59.0 are available; but I'm not on windows to check)

Thanks for Typst!

title: Add an example that numbers every 5th `par.line`
body: Proposed [on the forum](https://forum.typst.app/t/how-to-number-every-5th-line/1295/3) by Mc-Zen in October 2024.

title: Fix tab indentation in raw block with CRLF
body:
Fixes #6931 

Adding an extra condition to match with `\r\n` in `align_tabs` in [raw.rs](crates/typst-library/src/text/raw.rsl) seems to fix the indentation issue.

title: Support bibliography and citations linking to it in HTML
body:
A follow-on from #6894 that hews more closely to [the HTML spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/dpub-aria-1.1/#doc-bibliography) in terms of roles and also provides links from citations to their references.

I noticed that the work of finding the appropriate locations was already done when parsing the keys etc from hayagriva, so it seemed more appropriate to surface that in the `Works` data structure than to do it again. But I am still new to Typst internals, so please let me know if this is the correct approach or if there are downstream consequences of adding a field of which I might not be aware.

## Performance implications
The implications of adding the extra hash map to the `Works` data structure seem (from my naive point of view) acceptable because:
- Values are only added if the reference is actually printed in the bibliography. In other words, there is not necessarily an entry for every listing in a large `.bib` file. Thus while it does require some extra memory in the compiler, it is not a large amount (I don't think), and it scales linearly with the number of items that appear in the bibliography.

## Questions
It's not entirely clear to me why the `CiteGroup` doesn't automatically create a `LinkElem` in the HTML render pathway. I assume from #6917 that it has to be explicitly added for some reason to get an `<a>` tag to appear in HTML, but I would be happy for someone to point out that there is some easier way to get it than what I have done here.

With thanks to @willcrichton for his help in thinking about this change (though any and all deficiencies in the approach are my responsibility solely!)

title: Eliminate unnecessary `usize` usages from `typst-syntax`
body:
This follows the spirit of #6026: `usize` should only be used for ~~indices and lengths~~ things bounded by memory.

This PR is separated into disjoint commits to make reviewing easier.

Notes:
- For the precedences, I just went with the smallest type that fits all the values we use, so `u8`. There's also a case to be made for `u16`, but I think if there's ever a need for it, it can just be changed again then.
- For `MathRoot`, I think it's safe to say that we won't have syntax for roots with index greater than 255 in the future, so `u8` is the best choice.
- ~~For the other two, I just went with `u64` for obvious reasons. I'm actually not perfectly sure about these: They're not explicitly indices or lengths, but I don't know if it might not still be impossible for them to exceed `usize::MAX`... If so, then those two commits should of course be dropped.~~ Edit (see https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6942#pullrequestreview-3250067497): These are justified in their use of `usize`.

I checked all occurrences of `usize` in `typst-syntax` and everything besides what I changed here is justified (indices, ranges, and lengths).

title: Use Title Case for Doc Pages
body:
Fixes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/6934.

I also changed all references to the pages in question to use title case as well.

title: Add `default` argument to `array.join`
body:
Closes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/6891.

One open question is what to do when no default is provided and the array is empty. For now, I chose to return `none` (i.e., no change in behavior). `array.sum` and `array.product` raise an error in this case, so we might want to align with that.

title: Add Russian translation for footnote, email, telephone
body:
I double-checked with Wikipedia, just to be extra sure, and the translation actually matches perfectly (not really surprising, but yeah):

- https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Сноска
- https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Электронная_почта
- https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Телефон

Linking https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6619

title: Initial Hayagriva bump
body:
Related: #6842

This should unblock failing tests in #6171.

Does not bump to main since main has breaking changes directly related to that PR, hence the "initial" bump.

Among other hayagriva changes and fixes, `chicago-notes` has been changed to now display full citations by default, causing tests to fail. `chicago-shortened-notes` is now available for the old style (although still a bit different from before as the chicago directives changed).

`chicago-fullnotes` in theory no longer exists, but has been kept as an alias in hayagriva. This PR shall implement a warning so users using that style move to `chicago-notes`.

TODO:
- [x] Add the warning

title: Replace the non-existent `$math.arrow` with `$math.accent` in the docs for vector
body:
There's no dedicated anchor for `arrow`, so just point to the page.

Resolves #6908

(Not the best solution, but it's an internal function, and this is the only occurrence.)

title: Support footnotes in HTML
body:
This PR adds support for footnotes in HTML. The DOM structure is based on [Digital Publishing ARIA](https://www.w3.org/TR/dpub-aria-1.1/) and also relatively similar to what Pandoc emits. To implement footnotes in a final step, the PR first sets up some infrastructure, which is separated into individual commits. 

Currently, footnotes are always emitted at the very end of the document's `body`. In the future, I want to expose a container element that can be placed by the user to customize the position (this element already exists, but is internal for now). This could feasibly also be supported in paged export. When the user emits their own html or body tag, footnotes are currently ignored, but in the future, the user would be expected to then also place their own footnote container.

title: Show multi-page examples in typst-docs CLI
body: Resolves #6898 ~~**Update:** I'll refactor this PR in a few days.~~ Done. [Preview on netlify](https://68ce6851d84ac200080f2262--ydx-typst.netlify.app/reference/layout/block/#parameters-breakable)

title: Add an illustration for `par.{leading,spacing}` in docs
body:
This PR adds an illustration for `par.{leading,spacing}` in docs.
Old versions
There're many magic constants in the code, but most of them are lengths for aesthetic spacings, so I guess that's okay. Besides, the code is kind of overly automated. I think that is necessary to make sure it will survive in future Typst versions, considering that the rendered result are not tracked by git. ## Links - [Previous discussion on Discord Documentation Forge](https://discord.com/channels/1054443721975922748/1399326777540608041/1416012368873263125). - A Chinese version: https://github.com/typst-doc-cn/guide/pull/89

title: Fix footnote links in presence of styling
body: Fixes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/2430

title: Consistently ignore styles for tags
body: This ensures that style chains associated with tags never make it into shared trunk styles for groupings. Fixes a problem that https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6909 exhibits in combination with #6619.

title: Make `select_where!` usable outside of typst-library
body: This fixes a problem where `select_where!` couldn't be used in crates that do not directly depend on `smallvec`.

title: Expand tags even a bit more around groupings
body: Follow-up to https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6881 that goes even a little further. In the original PR, leading tags that were closed within a grouping are merged into the grouping, and the same for trailing tags. What wasn't merged into the grouping are leading tags that are closed by trailing tags. As a result, `#link("A")[A]` (just the link becomes the whole paragraph) resulted in the tag nesting `link > p`. With this PR, such tag pairings are also included in the grouping, resulting in the nesting `p > link`. This also makes auto-ID generation in HTML export a bit nicer.

title: Disambiguate names in the doc examples for `state`
body:
Resolve the confusion in [Using state for Caching in Typst — Is It Possible? - Questions - Typst Forum](https://forum.typst.app/t/using-state-for-caching-in-typst-is-it-possible/5961), where the author thought the placeholder for `eval` and the key for `state` are the same.

> I tried playing around with `state`, but I’m struggling to understand how to update it properly. The documentation mentions using `eval`, which I assume is because accessing a state value gives you its content, not a reference…

|                                 | Before | After  |
| ------------------------------- | ------ | ------ |
| variable                        | `x`/`s` | `star` |
| key for `state`                 | x      | star   |
| argument of the update function | `x`    | `old`  |
| placeholder for `eval`          | x      | ⭐      |

In addition, I change `{ … }` to `[ … ]` for the reason in #6844.

~~Preview: https://ydx-typst.netlify.app/reference/introspection/state/~~ (Outdated)

---

Besides, this PR doesn't add new simpler examples, as #6674 already added one in the `state.update` section.

title: Fix `Debug` impl for end tags
body: Small oversight in #6901 — we don't want a literal `{loc:?}`

title: Accessibility documentation
body: This guide is intended as a companion for the work in #6619. It explains to the user what they must pay attention to in order to create an accessible file.

title: Fix potential crash in `Debug` impl of `Property`
body: The current `Debug` impl can panic for internal fields. We don't have name metadata for them currently, but printing "internal" is still better than crashing.

title: More useful `Debug` impls for `Tag` and `Location`
body:
The current `Debug` impl for `Location` is very noisy because the number is 128 bit. For readability purposes, truncating it to 16 bit is better and the location probably is still low enough for debugging.

The current `Debug` impl for `Tag` is pretty useless since it does not print the location. It now does.

title: Fix off by one in tag expansion
body: A mistake made in https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6881 that was unfortunately not caught by the test I wrote because the behaviour can't be properly observed from Typst code as explained in the comment there. Now, I opted to write a custom check in Rust for those tests instead. This check could in the future expanded to cover more or all of the test suite, but that's quite a bit of work and there are a few problems and design decisions that I don't want to deal with right now.

title: Improve the docs for dictionary
body:
Resolves #6895

- Make it clear that the insertion **order** is the order they were inserted / declared _initially_. Also add a test for it.

- Document that the last value will **override** the others when dictionaries are added/joined/spread together.

- Document the **`(:..spread)`** syntax.

  I put it in a footnote, because it's really rare and I can't image any proper use case — why write `(:..a, ..b)` if you can write `a + b`?

- Change `"Berlin "` to `"Berlin"`.

  The typo dates back to [2023](https://github.com/typst/typst/commit/b471ac7d590abd2398ce25193b4e4df373bf2e9c#diff-3a020c42cc6500f1b1ecf127b5552edbe61c2b03b27b7f6d9890393aed7ab052).

- Add cross links and references.

title: Improve examples in the docs for under/over functions
body:
Annotations in under/over functions are also in math mode.
However, `"numbers"`, the previous example, is valid in both code and math modes. It makes some people write `$ underbrace(..., $m n$) $` and meet _Error: Unclosed delimiter_.
The new example adds `n + 1` to emphasize that it's in math mode.

There's another person suggesting `tilde(gamma) + ln n`, but I feel it's too long.

Besides, I change `+ ... +` to `+ dots.c +`, because mid-line ellipsis looks better among operators with horizontal symmetry.
[Ellipsis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipsis#In_mathematical_notation) also suggests this style.

title: Add a disclaimer about embedding PDFs
Fix panic on unescaped backslash in .sublime-syntax file (raw.syntaxes)
body:
See https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/4421#issuecomment-3267689889.

Fixes https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/4421.

So, everything is good, but I have no idea why the test keeps saying malformed range. I tried what feels like everything. It just doesn't wanna let it go. But without the error comment, previously it would panic, now it just gives the correct error from syntect (which is pretty long, but idk if it's bad). Also, the test parser is not aware of raw block, so it triggers error on `---` in raw block...

```text
 cargo test --workspace --test tests -- sublime
    Finished `test` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.33s
     Running src/tests.rs (target/debug/deps/tests-a1818e67b68d8e7b)
failed to collect tests
❌ range is malformed (tests/suite/text/raw.typ:110)
error: test failed, to rerun pass `-p typst-tests --test tests`
```

title: Ensure correct tag nesting with grouping rules
body:
This PR ensures that start/end tags are properly nested in the presence of grouping rules. Currently, end tags are only used for a few minor things, which is why the following problem remainted unnoticed. The code

```typ
A #link("B")[B]
```
led to a tag structure such as this:
```
start par
start link
end par
end link
```

The reason for this is the way grouping rules in realization interact with tags. Since the upcoming accessibility work relies heavily on end tags, it's important to fix this.

This PR implements the following rule: Tags at the edges of a grouping are kept with the group if their matching tag is within the grouping. Tags that are at the edges, but sandwhiched in between matching tags are also included.

This covers 90% of it. There is one small remaining issue with the following situation:

```typ
A #link("B")[B ]
```

Here, the trailing space is _before_ the end tag of the link, but the paragraph ends _before_ the trailing space (it's not included). In PDF-UA export, this would led to an error message regarding overlapping tags. However, there isn't any real overlap because the space will be destructed immediately after the paragraph is built since it's unsupported. For now, I've opted to special case this situation for the paragraph/space combo, since I think it's the only situation like this that can currently occur. If we were to have another grouping rule with such a setup, we'd have to see whether the inner element is also always destructed for it.

Note that overlapping tags are still possible, but this is inherent in how grouping works and should be fixed by the user if it happens. As an example:

```typ
A #link("BC")[B

C] D
```

A set structured is needed to efficiently determine whether a matching tag exists within the grouping. I first used `FxHashSet` for testing and even there, the performance is impact was very small. For the final version, I used an ordered set backed by a bump-allocated slice because why not. :) It's only a very small bit faster, but it's nice and the data structure could be used in other places, too.

title: Make clear that `Content::query_first` is naive
Remove unused `Styles::set_family`
Fix typos
body:
I ran the [`typos`](https://github.com/crate-ci/typos) tool on `typst/typst`, sifted through false positives, then added a couple of my own finds regarding units.

I'm not entirely sure about the *leaves* typo and those under the `tests` directory, because they're more part of the code rather than the comments.

title: Bump `codex`
body:
This is the companion PR for https://github.com/typst/codex/pull/114.

As mentioned on Discord,[^1] this PR won't change the appearance of emojis and symbols with the default font because emoji presentation sequences that have a corresponding text presentation that is supported by the main font will fall back to text presentations with the main font instead of causing a font fallback to a font that supports the emoji presentation.

I added a test which, for the reason mentioned above, does not show the difference between text presentation sequences and emoji presentation sequences.

[^1]: https://discord.com/channels/1054443721975922748/1277628305142452306/1413479337486975036

title: Use different colors for object keys and string-based values in JSON listings
body:
This simple PR should resolve https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/4635 by adding an `item` for the scope `meta.mapping.key.json string.quoted.double.json` to the default `raw` theme, changing the default color that is used for the keys within JSON objects. This makes it possible to differentiate keys from string-based values more easily.

I am currently not sure whether the color I've chosen so far is the best, so I am open for feedback here :) The changes themselves are hopefully trivial enough to still become part of the upcoming release.

title: Make show rule example in reference more idiomatic
body: The show rule example in the reference is really not idiomatic anymore. The example hadn't been updated since the show-set rule changes and demonstrated the bad practice of putting set rules into show rules instead of having separate show-set rules. It was also missing a `block` to benefit from stickiness, as discovered here: https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/6856

title: Add a link from `math.vec` to `math.{arrow,bold}` in docs
body:
LaTeX `\vec` ≠ Typst `vec` surprises some people, like Sinthoras who posted [How to write a vector arrow over a variable? Equivalent of LaTeX vec function? - Questions - Typst Forum](https://forum.typst.app/t/how-to-write-a-vector-arrow-over-a-variable-equivalent-of-latex-vec-function/5854).

I didn't mention `bold(upright(v))` or `hat(n)`, because it's too obvious.
There are also people who are confused by the missing space in `arrow(AB)`, but I don't think `math.vec` is the right place to explain.

title: Keep end of line whitespace glyphs
body:
This PR adjusts the inline layout such that whitespace at the end of a line (where a linebreak naturally occurred) is retained in the PDF output, so that text that was broken across lines still has spaces when copying it. Note that PDF readers employ various heuristics for text extraction of inaccessible PDFs and, for this reason, this does not currently have an effect in most viewers. However, it will have an effect in combination with PR #6619.

For layout purposes, the end of line whitespace is still ignored. This is achieved by routing pretty much all glyph access in layout through a new `Glyphs` container that transparently hides trimmed glyphs. Moreover, the trimmed glyphs get their advance width set to zero during building of the frames.

I've tried various other approaches before settling on the current one:
- Zeroing out the advance width immediately during line layout
- Extracting the end of line spaces into separate text items
- Having separate lists in the `ShapedText` for trimmed and untrimmed glyphs

However, those all suffered from performance problems (>10% slowdown on a pure lorem document) or complexity problems. The performance problem comes from the cloning of glyph lists. The individual glyphs are fairly large in memory (something that I'd like improve in the medium term) and also hold on to ref-counted `Font` objects. Modifying one means cloning the whole list, whereas currently in most cases, we can directly reuse the glyphs from the initial shaping pass during line layout. I tried optimizing with bump allocators and stuff, but that only helped a little. [^1]

In the end, the trimming approach I settled on turned out to be much simpler. I'm not 100% happy with it, but it seems good enough and I already spent too much time on this.

A final note: Newlines could also be handled like this. However, there is the challenge that they don't really have glyphs, so we'd have to repurpose the space glyph while making sure to always use ActualText in that case rather than writing a newline into the ToUnicode map. That's not currently possible with krilla's API, so we'd have to figure something out there first. I'm also not aware of another tool that does this. LibreOffice seems to be generally quite good in its text handling and newlines do not copy correctly out of accessible LibreOffice PDFs as far as I can tell. Still, an experiment with Typst confirmed that writing a space glyph with a newline as ActualText will lead to correct copy paste in Acrobat.

[^1]: There are small gains to be had compared to main with other allocations schemes, but nothing that seemed worth pursuing now.

title: Document and test `Sides<T>` parameters
body:
This PR is extracted from #6764 and resolves comments on `container.rs` in that PR.

- Document that `box.inset` and `box.outset` accept **dictionaries** containing top, right, x, y, rest, etc.

- Document what will happen if `box.inset` (or `page.margin`, `rect.stroke`, `table.stroke`) receives a dictionary with some keys **omitted**.

- Document that `box.inset` and similar parameters accept **relative** length, and add a test for that.

  Previously, there isn't any test that passes a ratio to `{box,block,rect,table,…}.inset`.

  The formula in the added test comes from [the `grow` function in typst-layout](https://github.com/typst/typst/blob/main/crates/typst-layout/src/pad.rs#L61-L93).

  It is important to mention that ratios are relative to the box size. People might mistakenly think they are relative to the size of available space, as in [Inset paragraph by exactly half a page - Questions - Typst Forum](https://forum.typst.app/t/inset-paragraph-by-exactly-half-a-page/5898/2).

## Things not covered in this PR

- Add links from `{table,grid}.inset` to `box.inset`.

  #6764 will add examples on `inset`. Theses links will be added together.

- Document that `page.margin` also accepts relative lengths.

  This feature is never tested and the behaviour looks buggy (for instance, `#set page(margin: (y: 20%), height: auto)`).
  Moreover, the only use case I know might deserve a dedicated API.

  > The only use case I know is [directly setting the width of the type area, instead of the paper width](https://typst-doc-cn.github.io/clreq/#directly-setting-the-width-of-the-type-area-instead-of-the-paper-width), like `#set page(margin: (x: (100% - 42em) / 2))`.


  Therefore, it requires more discussion.
